com.google.cloud.pubsub

Class Topic

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.google.cloud.pubsub.TopicInfo
      • com.google.cloud.pubsub.Topic
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Serializable

    public class Topic
extends TopicInfo
    A Google Cloud Pub/Sub topic. A topic is a named resource to which messages are sent by publishers. Subscribers can receive messages sent to a topic by creating subscriptions. Topic adds a layer of service-related functionality over TopicInfo. Objects of this class are immutable. To get a Topic object with the most recent information use reload() or reloadAsync().
    See Also:
    Pub/Sub Data Model, Serialized Form

      A builder for Topic objects.

      • delete

        public boolean delete()
        Deletes this topic.

        Example of deleting the topic. 

         boolean deleted = topic.delete();
 if (deleted) {
   // the topic was deleted
 } else {
   // the topic was not found
 }
        Returns:
        true if the topic was deleted, false if it was not found
        Throws:
        PubSubException - upon failure

      • deleteAsync

        public Future<Boolean> deleteAsync()
        Sends a request for deleting this topic. This method returns a Future object to consume the result. Future.get() returns true if the topic was deleted, false if it was not found.

        Example of asynchronously deleting the topic. 

         Future<Boolean> future = topic.deleteAsync();
 // ...
 boolean deleted = future.get();
 if (deleted) {
   // the topic was deleted
 } else {
   // the topic was not found
 }
        Throws:
        PubSubException - upon failure

      • reload

        public Topic reload()
        Fetches current topic's latest information. Returns null if the topic does not exist.

        Example of getting the topic's latest information. 

         Topic latestTopic = topic.reload();
 if (latestTopic == null) {
   // the topic was not found
 }
        Returns:
        a Topic object with latest information or null if not found
        Throws:
        PubSubException - upon failure

      • reloadAsync

        public Future<Topic> reloadAsync()
        Sends a request to fetch current topic's latest information. This method returns a Future object to consume the result. Future.get() returns a Topic object with latest information or null if not found.

        Example of asynchronously getting the topic's latest information. 

         Future<Topic> future = topic.reloadAsync();
 // ...
 Topic latestTopic = future.get();
 if (latestTopic == null) {
   // the topic was not found
 }
        Throws:
        PubSubException - upon failure

      • publish

        public String publish(Message message)
        Publishes a message to this topic. This method returns a service-generated id for the published message. Service-generated ids are guaranteed to be unique within the topic.

        Example of publishing one message to the topic. 

         Message message = Message.of("payload");
 String messageId = topic.publish(message);
        Parameters:
        message - the message to publish
        Returns:
        a unique service-generated id for the message
        Throws:
        PubSubException - upon failure, if the topic does not exist or if the message has empty payload and no attributes

      • publishAsync

        public Future<String> publishAsync(Message message)
        Sends a request for publishing a message to the this topic. This method returns a Future object to consume the result. Future.get() returns a service-generated id for the published message. Service-generated ids are guaranteed to be unique within the topic.

        Example of asynchronously publishing one message to the topic. 

         Message message = Message.of("payload");
 Future<String> future = topic.publishAsync(message);
 // ...
 String messageId = future.get();
        Parameters:
        message - the message to publish
        Returns:
        a Future for the unique service-generated id for the message

      • publish

        public List<String> publish(Message message,
                   Message... messages)
        Publishes a number of messages to this topic. This method returns a list of service-generated ids for the published messages. Service-generated ids are guaranteed to be unique within the topic.

        Example of publishing some messages to the topic. 

         Message message1 = Message.of("payload1");
 Message message2 = Message.of("payload2");
 List<String> messageIds = topic.publish(message1, message2);
        Parameters:
        message - the first message to publish
        messages - other messages to publish
        Returns:
        a list of unique, service-generated, ids. Ids are in the same order as the messages.
        Throws:
        PubSubException - upon failure, if the topic does not exist or if one of the messages has empty payload and no attributes

      • publishAsync

        public Future<List<String>> publishAsync(Message message,
                                Message... messages)
        Sends a request to publish a number of messages to this topic. This method returns a Future object to consume the result. Future.get() returns a list of service-generated ids for the published messages. Service-generated ids are guaranteed to be unique within the topic.

        Example of asynchronously publishing some messages to the topic. 

         Message message1 = Message.of("payload1");
 Message message2 = Message.of("payload2");
 Future<List<String>> future = topic.publishAsync(message1, message2);
 // ...
 List<String> messageIds = future.get();
        Parameters:
        message - the first message to publish
        messages - other messages to publish
        Returns:
        a Future for the unique, service-generated ids. Ids are in the same order as the messages.

      • publish

        public List<String> publish(Iterable<Message> messages)
        Publishes a number of messages to this topic. This method returns a list ofservice-generated ids for the published messages. Service-generated ids are guaranteed to be unique within the topic.

        Example of publishing a list of messages to the topic. 

         List<Message> messages = new LinkedList<>();
 messages.add(Message.of("payload1"));
 messages.add(Message.of("payload2"));
 List<String> messageIds = topic.publish(messages);
        Parameters:
        messages - the messages to publish
        Returns:
        a list of unique, service-generated, ids. Ids are in the same order as the messages.
        Throws:
        PubSubException - upon failure, if the topic does not exist or if one of the messages has empty payload and no attributes

      • publishAsync

        public Future<List<String>> publishAsync(Iterable<Message> messages)
        Sends a request to publish a number of messages to this topic. This method returns a Future object to consume the result. Future.get() returns a list of service-generated ids for the published messages. Service-generated ids are guaranteed to be unique within the topic.

        Example of asynchronously publishing a list of messages to the topic. 

         List<Message> messages = new LinkedList<>();
 messages.add(Message.of("payload1"));
 messages.add(Message.of("payload2"));
 Future<List<String>> future = topic.publishAsync(messages);
 // ...
 List<String> messageIds = future.get();
        Parameters:
        messages - the messages to publish
        Returns:
        a Future for the unique, service-generated ids. Ids are in the same order as the messages.

      • listSubscriptions

        public Page<SubscriptionId> listSubscriptions(PubSub.ListOption... options)
        Lists the identities of the subscriptions for this topic. This method returns a Page object that can be used to consume paginated results. Use PubSub.ListOption to specify the page size or the page token from which to start listing subscriptions.

        Example of listing subscriptions for the topic, specifying the page size. 

         Page<SubscriptionId> subscriptions = topic.listSubscriptions(ListOption.pageSize(100));
 Iterator<SubscriptionId> subscriptionIterator = subscriptions.iterateAll();
 while (subscriptionIterator.hasNext()) {
   SubscriptionId subscription = subscriptionIterator.next();
   // do something with the subscription identity
 }
        Throws:
        PubSubException - upon failure

      • listSubscriptionsAsync

        public Future<AsyncPage<SubscriptionId>> listSubscriptionsAsync(PubSub.ListOption... options)
        Sends a request for listing the identities of subscriptions for this topic. This method returns a Future object to consume the result. Future.get() returns an AsyncPage object that can be used to asynchronously handle paginated results. Use PubSub.ListOption to specify the page size or the page token from which to start listing subscriptions.

        Example of asynchronously listing subscriptions for the topic, specifying the page size. 

         Future<AsyncPage<SubscriptionId>> future =
     topic.listSubscriptionsAsync(ListOption.pageSize(100));
 // ...
 AsyncPage<SubscriptionId> subscriptions = future.get();
 Iterator<SubscriptionId> subscriptionIterator = subscriptions.iterateAll();
 while (subscriptionIterator.hasNext()) {
   SubscriptionId subscription = subscriptionIterator.next();
   // do something with the subscription identity
 }

      • getPolicy

        public Policy getPolicy()
        Returns the IAM access control policy for this topic. Returns null if the topic was not found.

        Example of getting the topic's policy. 

         Policy policy = topic.getPolicy();
 if (policy == null) {
   // topic was not found
 }
        Throws:
        PubSubException - upon failure

      • getPolicyAsync

        public Future<Policy> getPolicyAsync()
        Sends a request for getting the IAM access control policy for this topic. This method returns a Future object to consume the result. Future.get() returns the requested policy or null if the topic was not found.

        Example of asynchronously getting the topic's policy. 

         Future<Policy> future = topic.getPolicyAsync();
 // ...
 Policy policy = future.get();
 if (policy == null) {
   // topic was not found
 }
        Throws:
        PubSubException - upon failure

      • replacePolicy

        public Policy replacePolicy(Policy newPolicy)
        Sets the IAM access control policy for this topic. Replaces any existing policy. This method returns the new policy.

        It is recommended that you use the read-modify-write pattern. This pattern entails reading the project's current policy, updating it locally, and then sending the modified policy for writing. Cloud IAM solves the problem of conflicting processes simultaneously attempting to modify a policy by using the etag property. This property is used to verify whether the policy has changed since the last request. When you make a request with an etag value, the value in the request is compared with the existing etag value associated with the policy. The policy is written only if the etag values match. If the etags don't match, a PubSubException is thrown, denoting that the server aborted update. If an etag is not provided, the policy is overwritten blindly.

        Example of replacing the topic's policy. 

         Policy policy = topic.getPolicy();
 Policy updatedPolicy = policy.toBuilder()
     .addIdentity(Role.viewer(), Identity.allAuthenticatedUsers())
     .build();
 updatedPolicy = topic.replacePolicy(updatedPolicy);
        Throws:
        PubSubException - upon failure

      • replacePolicyAsync

        public Future<Policy> replacePolicyAsync(Policy newPolicy)
        Sends a request to set the IAM access control policy for this topic. Replaces any existing policy. This method returns a Future object to consume the result. Future.get() returns the new policy.

        It is recommended that you use the read-modify-write pattern. This pattern entails reading the project's current policy, updating it locally, and then sending the modified policy for writing. Cloud IAM solves the problem of conflicting processes simultaneously attempting to modify a policy by using the etag property. This property is used to verify whether the policy has changed since the last request. When you make a request with an etag value, the value in the request is compared with the existing etag value associated with the policy. The policy is written only if the etag values match. If the etags don't match, Future.get() will throw a ExecutionException caused by a PubSubException, denoting that the server aborted update. If an etag is not provided, the policy is overwritten blindly.

        Example of asynchronously replacing the topic's policy. 

         Policy policy = topic.getPolicy();
 Policy updatedPolicy = policy.toBuilder()
     .addIdentity(Role.viewer(), Identity.allAuthenticatedUsers())
     .build();
 Future<Policy> future = topic.replacePolicyAsync(updatedPolicy);
 // ...
 updatedPolicy = future.get();
        Throws:
        PubSubException - upon failure

      • testPermissions

        public List<Boolean> testPermissions(List<String> permissions)
        Returns the permissions that a caller has on this topic.

        You typically don't call this method if you're using Google Cloud Platform directly to manage permissions. This method is intended for integration with your proprietary software, such as a customized graphical user interface. For example, the Cloud Platform Console tests IAM permissions internally to determine which UI should be available to the logged-in user.

        Example of testing whether the caller has the provided permissions on the topic. 

         List<String> permissions = new LinkedList<>();
 permissions.add("pubsub.topics.get");
 List<Boolean> testedPermissions = topic.testPermissions(permissions);
        Returns:
        A list of booleans representing whether the caller has the permissions specified (in the order of the given permissions)
        Throws:
        PubSubException - upon failure
        See Also:
        Permissions and Roles

      • testPermissionsAsync

        public Future<List<Boolean>> testPermissionsAsync(List<String> permissions)
        Sends a request to get the permissions that a caller has on this topic.

        You typically don't call this method if you're using Google Cloud Platform directly to manage permissions. This method is intended for integration with your proprietary software, such as a customized graphical user interface. For example, the Cloud Platform Console tests IAM permissions internally to determine which UI should be available to the logged-in user.

        Example of asynchronously testing whether the caller has the provided permissions on the topic. 

         List<String> permissions = new LinkedList<>();
 permissions.add("pubsub.topics.get");
 Future<List<Boolean>> future = topic.testPermissionsAsync(permissions);
 // ...
 List<Boolean> testedPermissions = future.get();
        Returns:
        A Future object to consume the result. Future.get() returns a list of booleans representing whether the caller has the permissions specified (in the order of the given permissions)
        Throws:
        PubSubException - upon failure
        See Also:
        Permissions and Roles
